content.title: Nephrotic Syndrome
content.summary: Clinical syndrome characterized by heavy proteinuria (>3.5 g/day), hypoalbuminemia, peripheral edema, and hyperlipidemia, caused by glomerular podocyte injury from various primary and secondary etiologies
key_points: Defined by proteinuria >3.5 g/day (or uPCR >3.5 g/g), hypoalbuminemia <3 g/dL
Classic triad: heavy proteinuria + hypoalbuminemia + peripheral edema
Primary causes: MCD, FSGS, membranous nephropathy
Treatment: cause-specific + supportive (diuretics, ACEi/ARB, statins, anticoagulation if severe)

statement.text: Nephrotic syndrome is a clinical constellation resulting from increased glomerular permeability to protein: heavy proteinuria (>3.5 g/24h), hypoalbuminemia (<3 g/dL), peripheral edema, and hyperlipidemia. The underlying pathology is podocyte injury, which can result from primary glomerular diseases (minimal change, FSGS, membranous nephropathy) or secondary causes (diabetes, amyloidosis, lupus). Complications include venous thromboembolism, infection, and hyperlipidemia-related cardiovascular disease.
statement.formal: Nephrotic Syndrome = Proteinuria >3.5 g/day + Albumin <3 g/dL + Edema + Hyperlipidemia

explanation.intuition: The glomerulus normally keeps protein in the blood. In nephrotic syndrome, the filter leaks, allowing albumin to spill into urine. The liver tries to compensate by making more albumin but also ramps up lipid production (they're made together). Low albumin reduces oncotic pressure, causing fluid to leak into tissues (edema). Lost albumin also carries away antithrombin III, increasing clot risk.
explanation.key_insight: Think of the complications as linked to what's lost or what's overproduced: albumin loss → edema, VTE (lost anticoagulant proteins), infection (lost immunoglobulins); lipid overproduction → hyperlipidemia and accelerated atherosclerosis.
explanation.technical_details: Podocytes are specialized epithelial cells that form the slit diaphragm—the final barrier preventing protein loss. Injury to podocytes (fusion, effacement) causes loss of size/charge selectivity. In selective proteinuria (MCD), only albumin is lost; in non-selective (FSGS, membranous), larger proteins also escape. The liver increases synthesis of albumin, lipoproteins, and coagulation factors, creating a hypercoagulable state.

definitions_glossary.nephrotic_syndrome: Clinical syndrome of heavy proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, edema, and hyperlipidemia from glomerular disease
definitions_glossary.proteinuria: Protein in urine; >3.5 g/day or uPCR >3.5 g/g defines nephrotic range
definitions_glossary.hypoalbuminemia: Serum albumin <3 g/dL, resulting from urinary losses exceeding hepatic synthesis
definitions_glossary.podocyte: Specialized glomerular epithelial cell forming the slit diaphragm filtration barrier
definitions_glossary.minimal_change_disease: Most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children; podocyte effacement without visible LM changes
definitions_glossary.focal_segmental_glomerulosclerosis: Segmental scarring of some glomeruli; common cause of steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome
definitions_glossary.membranous_nephropathy: Subepithelial immune deposits causing GBM thickening; most common primary cause in adults
definitions_glossary.lipiduria: Lipid in urine; oval fat bodies and 'Maltese cross' pattern under polarized light
definitions_glossary.edema: Tissue swelling from interstitial fluid accumulation due to low oncotic pressure
definitions_glossary.venous_thromboembolism: DVT or PE; common complication due to loss of anticoagulant proteins
definitions_glossary.antithrombin_iii: Anticoagulant protein lost in urine, contributing to hypercoagulable state
definitions_glossary.selective_proteinuria: Primarily albumin loss (MCD); contrasted with non-selective (larger proteins too)

pathophysiology.mechanism: Glomerular podocyte injury disrupts the slit diaphragm, allowing protein leakage. Albumin is the primary protein lost due to its size and charge. The liver compensates by increasing albumin synthesis, but production cannot match losses. Concurrently, hepatic lipoprotein synthesis increases, causing hyperlipidemia. Urinary loss of antithrombin III, protein C, protein S creates a hypercoagulable state. Loss of immunoglobulins and complement factors increases infection risk.

primary_glomerular: Minimal change disease (MCD)—most common in children
Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS)—most common in African Americans
Membranous nephropathy—most common primary cause in white adults
secondary: Diabetic nephropathy—most common cause of nephrotic syndrome overall

complications.vte: 10-40% incidence; renal vein thrombosis especially in membranous nephropathy
complications.infection: Encapsulated organisms (Streptococcus pneumoniae, H. flu); loss of IgG and complement
complications.aki: From intravascular volume depletion, sepsis, bilateral renal vein thrombosis
complications.hyperlipidemia: LDL elevated; contributes to cardiovascular disease

clinical_findings.edema: Periorbital in morning, pedal later in day; may progress to anasarca

laboratory_findings.urinalysis: Heavy proteinuria, lipiduria (oval fat bodies, Maltese crosses)
laboratory_findings.complement: Normal in most primary causes; low C3/C4 suggests lupus or MPGN

diagnostic_workup: Confirm nephrotic-range proteinuria (24-hour urine or spot uPCR)
Check serum albumin, lipid panel, renal function
Screen for secondary causes: glucose/A1c, ANA, HBV/HCV/HIV, SPEP/UPEP
Renal biopsy for definitive diagnosis (adults; children often treated empirically)

supportive.edema_management: Salt restriction (<2g Na/day), loop diuretics ± thiazide if resistant
supportive.proteinuria_reduction: ACEi or ARB—reduce proteinuria and slow progression
supportive.vte_prophylaxis: Anticoagulation if albumin <2-2.5 g/dL or additional risk factors; consider for severe membranous

minimal_change_disease.treatment: High-dose prednisone (1 mg/kg/day × 4-8 weeks, then taper)

fsgs.response: Variable; primary FSGS responds better than secondary

membranous_nephropathy.treatment: Rituximab (first-line for PLA2R+) or CNI + steroids
membranous_nephropathy.observation: Spontaneous remission in 30%—observe for 6-12 months if low risk

monitoring.follow_up: Proteinuria, creatinine, albumin every 1-3 months during treatment

definition.@value: Clinical syndrome characterized by heavy proteinuria (>3.5 g/day), hypoalbuminemia, peripheral edema, and hyperlipidemia, caused by glomerular podocyte injury

skos.scopeNote: Covers definition, primary and secondary causes, complications, diagnostic workup, and cause-specific treatment
skos.example: A 5-year-old boy with periorbital edema, 4+ proteinuria, serum albumin 1.8 g/dL, normal C3—classic presentation of minimal change disease

learning_objectives: Define nephrotic syndrome using clinical and laboratory criteria
Recognize major complications including VTE and infection
Apply cause-specific treatment for MCD, FSGS, and membranous nephropathy
clinical_pearls: Membranous nephropathy has highest VTE risk—especially renal vein thrombosis
MCD in children: empiric steroids without biopsy is standard (95% respond)
Low C3/C4 suggests lupus nephritis or MPGN—not typical of MCD, FSGS, or membranous
PLA2R antibody: positive in 70-80% of primary membranous; useful for diagnosis and monitoring
Infection risk: vaccinate against pneumococcus; low threshold for antibiotics if sick
SGLT2 inhibitors reduce proteinuria even in non-diabetic glomerular disease

board_yield.nephrology_boards: Very High - detailed pathophysiology and treatment
board_yield.pediatric_boards: High - MCD is most common childhood nephrotic syndrome

common_misconceptions: Nephrotic syndrome always requires biopsy (false—children with classic presentation treated empirically)
Low albumin is from poor nutrition (false—from urinary losses despite adequate intake)
Loop diuretics don't work in nephrotic syndrome (false—may need higher doses due to albumin binding)
